Project Number: 45147 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
 
Supporting Public Management through 
e-Government Capacity Development 
(Financed by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Information and communication technology (ICT) has had an enormous impact on the 
way governments carry out their functions. The use of appropriate ICT tools and applications 
has enabled governments to provide more efficient services to improve their communication and 
transform their relationship with citizens, businesses, and other public sector institutions. ICT 
has also been increasingly used as a tool to reduce corruption. However, the weak organization 
capacity of government agencies in developing member countries (DMCs), in terms of ICT 
adoption and project implementation, is identified as a major reason for failure to reap the 
potential benefits of e-government projects. To address this constraint, in 2009 ADB approved 
regional capacity development technical assistance (TA),1 which developed an e-government 
capability maturity model (CMM)—a tool for assessing the maturity of an organization based on 
a set of criteria vis-à-vis the requirements of a given e-government project. The model was 
applied  to  three  pilot  ICT  agencies  in  Mongolia,  the  Philippines,  and  Viet  Nam.  The  pilot 
countries noted that the TA raised awareness of the importance of e-government capacity 
development across various levels of government.  
 
2.  The  current  TA  will  support  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  public  sector  e-
government projects in selected DMCs. It will focus on specific projects that are at the design or 
implementation  stage,  and  will  develop  e-government  toolkits  specific  to  the  use  of  a  tax 
administration management information system (TAMIS) and a social security administration 
information  system  (SSAIS).  The  TA  will  benefit  other  DMCs  through  various  knowledge 
products that will be developed. Fact-finding missions were carried out for Tajikistan (22–23 
September 2011), Viet Nam (28–29 September 2011), and Sri Lanka (13–14 October 2011) to 
discuss and agree on the impact, outcomes, outputs, and implementation arrangements of the 
TA. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  During the final workshop of the 2009 regional TA, participating countries expressed 
some concern that the e-governance initiative could not be sustained without external support 
and that further assistance was needed to customize the e-government CMM to their specific 
country situation. Further, the CMM tool would be more relevant if it were fine-tuned to specific 
e-government applications or a DMC’s specific project needs. Most DMCs, with still very limited 
capacity, resources, and hands-on experience in adopting such a tool, would find this next step 
extremely difficult without continued guidance and support.  
 
4.  To address these challenges, the current TA is to help sustain the momentum gained 
from  the  initial  e-governance  capacity  development  project  and,  more  importantly,  to 
complement ongoing ICT-supported public sector operations. The ADB regional departments 
concerned were asked to identify potential e-government projects to be supported in selected 
DMCs  where ADB assistance can be relevant and useful in ongoing public sector reform 
programs, especially in areas where ADB has already provided or currently provides support. 
Priority  e-government  applications  and  participating  DMCs  were  identified  through  a 
                                                
1   ADB.  2009.  Technical  Assistance  on  Improving  Public  Services  Through  Information  and  Communication 
Technology. Manila. (REG 7351) aimed to enhance the organizational capacity of governments of three countries 
(Mongolia, the Philippines, and Viet Nam) to formulate, direct, and implement e-government projects in the sectors 
of agriculture, education, health, and public administration. The TA included (i) developing an e-government CMM 
and ICT project guidebook, (ii) providing associated training and introducing available capacity development 
programs, and (iii) supporting strategies for development, as appropriate.

brainstorming seminar under the Governance and Public Management Community of Practice 
and fact-finding missions during TA preparation. 
 
5.   Of  the  three  countries,  Sri  Lanka  and  Tajikistan  need  assistance  for  TAMIS;  and 
Tajikistan and Viet Nam need assistance for SSAIS. 
 
6.  Specific e-government domain areas, and their concomitant challenges, in the proposed 
focus countries—Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, and Viet Nam—include the following: 
 
(i)       In Sri Lanka, the ADB-financed Fiscal Management Reform Project (FMRP) was 
implemented in 2005–2008. It supported the government in strengthening its 
public finance by improving the public resource management system, promoting 
fiscal discipline, and supporting fiscal decentralization. In particular, it sought to 
create  an  enabling  environment  to  foster  mobilization  of  tax  revenues  and 
improve  effectiveness  of  public  expenditures.  Designed  to  take  a  phased 
approach, the FMRP (now phase 2) will focus on implementation through setting 
up a tax and treasury management information system. In an effort to support the 
FMRP  (phase  2),  ADB  approved  a  loan  to  finance  the  Fiscal  Management 
Efficiency  Project  (FMEP)  to  develop  a  revenue  administration  management 
information  system.3   In  consultation  with  the  Public  Management,  Financial 
Sector, and Trade Division of ADB South Asia Department, the TA will support 
FMEP through e-government capacity development. The Ministry of Finance and 
Planning expressed strong interest in receiving technical support for the FMEP, 
suggesting that the TA focus on training government officials for more advanced 
tax and fiscal administration.  
(ii)       For Tajikistan, ADB approved a $45 million grant in March 2011 to strengthen the 
country’s social protection programs and tax management reforms. 4 The Ministry 
of Labor and Social Protection will be provided with support to carry out a pilot 
program for non-cash-based pension payments using plastic cards and another 
pilot program for consolidation of a multiple benefits system. Also, assistance will 
be provided to the State Tax Committee to support the introduction of electronic 
filing  of  tax  returns  by  large  taxpayers  and  other  measures  to  improve 
transparency and tax collection. The Public Management, Financial Sector, and 
Trade Division of ADB Central and West Asia Department requested TA support 
for  the  e-government  components  of  the  grant  program.  The  State  Tax 
Committee and Ministry of Labor and Social Protection, the government agencies 
responsible  for  tax  management  reform  and  the  social  protection  program 
respectively, expressed strong interest in receiving technical support for their e-
government projects.  
                                                
3  ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Technical 
Assistance Grant to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the Fiscal Management Efficiency Project ). 
Manila. The $50 million loan was approved on 15 April 2010. Currently, the project is in the bidding process to 
procure a main contractor for the revenue administration management information system. 
4  ADB. 2011. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Grant to the

was approved on 12 Apr 2011. The program aims to strengthen public resource management in Tajikistan through 
improved tax policy and administration, more effective and efficient social safety net programs, and improved 
public financial management.

3 
(iii)       In  Viet  Nam,  the  government  committed  to  developing  a  modern,  fair,  and 
transparent  social  security  system  through  the  recent  social  security 
administration reform proposal of Viet Nam Social Security (VSS). The proposal 
is intended to strengthen the operating efficiency and capacity of VSS, with a 
focus on improved business processes and information management, enhanced 
service  to  clients,  better  transparency,  and  strengthened  management  of 
reserves. VSS emphasizes the importance of ICT in reforming social security 
administration but also expresses concern about the agency’s lack of institutional 
capacity to implement a complex e-government project such as the SSAIS. It has 
asked for ADB support to develop e-governance capacity and help the agency 
develop the SSAIS as part of its Social Security Administration Modernization 
Program. 
7.  Results of the fact-finding missions confirm the urgent need to enhance e-government 
capacity to implement e-governance projects. The TA will develop e-government toolkits for the 
TAMIS and SSAIS and adapt them for participating countries to enhance their capacity for  
e-government projects through e-government capacity development programs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be improved government work productivity and better public 
services  using  e-government  applications.  The  outcome  will  be  successful  e-government 
projects and strengthened e-governance capacity of government agencies concerned in the 
participating DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will maximize current knowledge and experiences through collaboration with 
notable  development  agencies  in  the  Republic  of  Korea  such  as  the  National  Information 
Society Agency,5 the National IT Industry Promotion Agency,6 and the Korea Development 
Institute.7 Given the complex nature of e-government projects—both ICT and public sector 
reform  need  to  be  considered  together—learning  from  countries  with  actual  experience  in 
successfully  applying  ICT  to  various  public  sector  reform  initiatives  will  be  important.  The 
Republic of Korea is widely recognized as a rich learning source of best practices in public 
sector reforms and e-government. Moreover, this collaboration is in line with the Republic of 
Korea–ADB  Knowledge  Partnership  agreement,  signed  in  May  2011,  to  open  up  new 
opportunities  for  maximizing  knowledge  sharing  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  The  TA  will  also 
collaborate  with  the  United  Nations  Asian  and  Pacific Training  Centre for  Information  and 
                                                
5  The National Information Society Agency has been managing the information technology learning program, 
designed to promote international cooperation to build human capacity among developing countries, with financial 
support from the Ministry of Public Administration and Security.  
6  The mission of the National IT Industry Promotion Agency, a government agency under the Ministry of Knowledge 
Economy, is to promote the national ICT industry. As part of economic cooperation and knowledge partnerships 
with developing countries, it has provided TA to various e-government projects in developing countries. 
7  The Korea Development Institute, an autonomous policy-oriented research organization under the Ministry of 
Strategy and Finance, is an economic think tank. In an effort to share the country’s economic development 
experiences, the Ministry of Strategy and Finance launched the Knowledge Sharing Program in 2004, with the 
Korea Development Institute implementing the program.

4           
Communication Technology for Development (UN-APCICT)8 for the dissemination of knowledge 
gained from the project to other developing countries outside of the focus countries. 
 
10.  The TA will have four major outputs: (i) development of e-government toolkits on the 
TAMIS; (ii) development of e-government toolkits on the SSAIS; (iii) capacity development for 
the TAMIS  and  SSAIS for the focus countries (Sri  Lanka, Tajikistan,  and  Viet  Nam);  and  
(iv) knowledge dissemination and awareness-raising about the e-governance initiative. 
 
(i)       Outputs 1 and 2. The e-government toolkits on the TAMIS and SSAIS will be 
developed for the priority areas selected from the e-government CMM ranging 
from  e-government  strategy,  business  process,  organizational  capacity,  and 
governance of information technology. The e-government toolkits will be tailored 
to  specific  situations  and  requirements  from  each  participating  country.  In 
addition, e-government toolkits will be made available online through the UN-
APCICT website. 
(ii)       Output  3.  In  the  course  of  implementing  components  1  and  2,  specific  e-
government capacity development programs focusing on the TAMIS and SSAIS 
will be developed and adapted for the government agencies concerned. These 
will include the development of knowledge products customized for Sri Lanka, 
Tajikistan, and Viet Nam; and in-country training and consultations to assist the 
governments  in  formulating,  directing,  and/or  implementing  the  TAMIS  and 
SSAIS projects.  
(iii)       Output 4. The TA will have a regional conference to disseminate knowledge 
products  such  as  e-government  toolkits  and  to  share  e-government  project 
experiences  for  the  benefit  of  participating  countries  as  well  as  other 
nonparticipating DMCs.  
 
11.  A number of risks and assumptions are associated with the TA outputs and outcome.  
For the outcome, strong ownership by the participating governments in the form of continuous 
support for the e-governance capacity development initiative beyond the TA is assumed. Risks 
are associated with the lack of country resources and weak commitment from the governments 
to implement the interventions necessary for the e-government capacity development initiatives. 
These risks will be mitigated through close collaboration with ADB regional departments and 
resident missions concerned to strengthen the link between the e-government initiatives and 
related public sector reform programs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  and 
administered by ADB. The Government of the Republic of Korea and UN-APCICT will make in-
kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
                                                
8  UN-APCICT is a regional institute of the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific 
(UNESCAP), mandated to build human and institutional capacity for ICT among UNESCAP member countries.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA  and  be  responsible  for  the  overall 
management and monitoring of activities. The implementing agencies for the respective country 
components will be the Ministry of Finance and Planning in Sri Lanka, the State Tax Committee 
and the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection in Tajikistan, and VSS in Viet Nam. ADB will 
closely collaborate with the government agencies of the Republic of Korea and will make a 
formal  agreement  for  their  in-kind  contributions,  if  necessary.  The  TA  will  work  in  close 
coordination with ADB’s regional departments and resident missions. 
 
14.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  from  January  2012  to  June  2013.  It  will  require  two 
international consultants, one each to work on the TAMIS and SSAIS for the duration of the TA 
(6  person-months  each,  on  an  intermittent  basis).  The  international  consultants  will  be 
responsible for (i) overall project management in each domain area; (ii) the assessment of  
e-government  capacity  of  the  government  agencies  concerned;  (iii)  the  development  of  
e-government toolkits for a specific application; (iv) the refinement of the e-government CMM 
and ICT guidebook, as necessary; (v) conduct of in-country training; and (vi) the development of 
knowledge products for the regional conference. Three national consultants will be contracted to 
liaise and facilitate communication between the respective government and ADB’s project team, 
and to provide research support (4 person-months each). An experienced national research 
consultant will assist in developing the e-government toolkits and monitoring project progress 
(12 person-months, on an intermittent basis). All consultants will be recruited on an individual 
basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). All disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with the Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of 
reference  for  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  Confirmation  of  the  no-objection  of  DMC 
governments will be obtained before commencing or financing activities in the participating 
DMCs. 
 
15.  The TA will be monitored through regular progress reports, consensus-building activities 
with  workshops,  and  an  informal  survey  to  gain  comments  and  suggestions  from  key 
stakeholders.  The  TA  will  include  an  inception  workshop  in  the  Republic  of  Korea  or  the 
Philippines 1 month after consultants are mobilized. A series of country workshops and a 
regional workshop may also be held in collaboration with the Government of the Republic of 
Korea and UN-APCICT. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund for Supporting 
Public Management through e-Government Capacity Development, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  A total of 36 person-months of national and international consulting services will be 
required to ensure that the technical assistance (TA) project is effectively managed and the 
intended outcome is achieved. The TA will require 12 person-months of international consultant 
inputs, and 24 person-months of national consultant inputs.  All consultants will be recruited as 
individuals in accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
A.  E-Government Specialist on Tax Administration Management Information Systems 
(international, 6 person-months intermittent) 
 
2.  The specialist will report to the ADB project officer and perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)      Provide overall project management for the capacity development activities for 
the tax administration management information system (TAMIS), including status 
reporting  to  the  ADB  project  officer;  manage  the  research  and  national 
consultants; and communicate with government officials and other stakeholders 
as needed. 
(ii)      Develop  a  traceable  project  plan  through  consultation  with  all  stakeholders, 
including the ADB project officer, government officials, and other consultants.  
(iii)      Assess the e-governance capacity of the government agencies concerned based 
on the e-government capability maturity model (CMM) and identify priority areas 
for the TAMIS project in participating countries. 
(iv)       Develop specific knowledge materials and tools for the identified priority areas in 
the TAMIS projects of participating countries.  
(v)       Plan, organize, and conduct training on the TAMIS for each participating country, 
with training materials developed for the event.  
(vi)       Develop an e-government toolkit on the TAMIS that can be easily customized to 
other DMCs. 
(vii)      Refine the e-government CMM and ICT guidebook, as necessary.1 
(viii)      Plan and organize a regional knowledge-sharing conference, in collaboration with 
stakeholders  concerned,  with  knowledge-sharing  materials  developed  for  the 
event. 
(ix)      Carry out  other duties that are within his/her specialization as may be assigned 
by the ADB project officer. 
 
B.  E-Government Specialist on Social Security Administration Information Systems 
(international, 6 person-months intermittent)

(i)       Provide overall project management for the capacity development activities for 
the social security administration information system (SSAIS), including reporting 
on the status of activities to the ADB project officer, managing the research and

(ix)  Carry out any other duties within his/her specialization as may be assigned by 
the ADB project officer. 
 
C.  National  e-Government  Specialists  (three  specialists,  4  person-months  each, 
intermittent, to be based in each participating country) 
 
4.  The specialists, who will work under the supervision and guidance of the international  
e-government specialists on the TAMIS and the SSAIS, and the ADB project officer, will perform 
the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Report  updates  on  project  progress,  issues,  and  efforts  to  the  international  
e-government specialists. 
(ii)  Liaise  and  support  communication  (including  simultaneous  interpretation) 
between  government  officials,  the  ADB  project  officer,  and  international  
e-government specialists to coordinate project activities. 
(iii)  Provide the international e-government specialists with language support, local 
knowledge, and up-to-date information on current national conditions, policies, 
and pertinent issues, to help with the development of knowledge products and 
implementation of training programs.  
(iv)  Oversee translation of the e-government toolkits on tax management and/or the 
SSAIS,  and  all  knowledge  products  and  training  materials  into  Russian  and 
Vietnamese. 
(v)  Carry out any other duties within his/her specialization as may be assigned by 
the international e-government specialists and the ADB project officer. 
 
D.  National ICT Research Consultant (12 person-months intermittent, to be based in the 
Philippines) 
 
5.  The consultant, who will work under the supervision and guidance of the ADB project 
officer, will perform the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Monitor  project  progress,  collect  status  reports  from  the  international  
e-government specialists, and organize reports for the ADB project officer.

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  Work  with  the  international  e-government  specialists  in  developing  the  
e-government toolkits. 
(iii)  Refine and finalize both toolkits, as well as the enhanced e-government CMM 
and ICT guidebook, in line with ADB’s publishing guidelines.  
(iv)  Collect experiences and feedback, and compile all information to be utilized in 
the development of the e-government toolkits and reports on lessons. 
(v)  Carry  out  any  other  duties  that  are  within  his/her  specialization  as  may  be 
assigned  by  the  international  e-government  specialists  and  the  ADB  project 
officer.
